intro: Tupacamaria hysterantha, commonly known as the yellow bell, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and is characterized by its showy, yellow-orange bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and canyons. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are often branched and woody. Tupacamaria hysterantha is known for its ability to thrive in drought conditions, making it an important plant in xerophytic ecosystems.
